question.text: (CBSE 2023) Which tissue is responsible for movement in our body?
question.explanation: Muscular tissue contracts and relaxes to produce movement. Three types: skeletal, smooth, cardiac.

question.text: (SEBA 2023) The tissue that connects bone to bone is:
question.explanation: Ligament: bone to bone (elastic, yellow fibers). Tendon: muscle to bone (white fibers, less elastic).

question.text: (CBSE 2022) Which of these is a simple permanent tissue?
question.explanation: Simple permanent tissues: parenchyma, collenchyma, sclerenchyma. Complex tissues: xylem and phloem.

question.text: (SEBA 2022) The tissue that transports food in plants is:
question.explanation: Phloem transports organic nutrients (photosynthates) from leaves to other parts. Bidirectional flow.

question.text: (CBSE 2021) Which epithelial tissue is found in kidney tubules?
question.explanation: Cuboidal epithelium: cube-shaped cells, found in kidney tubules, salivary glands, for secretion and absorption.

question.text: (SEBA 2021) The dead element of phloem is:
question.explanation: Phloem fibers (bast fibers) are dead, provide mechanical support. Sieve tubes, companion cells, phloem parenchyma are living.

question.text: (CBSE 2020) Which tissue stores fat in our body?
question.explanation: Adipose tissue stores fat (triglycerides) as energy reserve, insulation, cushioning. Found under skin, around organs.

question.text: (SEBA 2020) The tissue present in the growing tips of roots and stems is:
question.explanation: Meristematic tissue: actively dividing cells, found at growing tips (apical meristem), responsible for growth.

question.text: (CBSE 2019) Which muscle tissue shows rhythmic contractions throughout life?
question.explanation: Cardiac muscle: involuntary, rhythmic contractions (heartbeat), branched cells with intercalated discs.

question.text: (SEBA 2019) The tissue that transports water in plants is:
question.explanation: Xylem transports water and minerals from roots to leaves. Unidirectional flow. Contains tracheids, vessels, xylem parenchyma, fibers.

question.text: (CBSE 2018) Which connective tissue has fluid matrix?
question.explanation: Blood: fluid connective tissue, plasma (matrix) + formed elements (RBCs, WBCs, platelets). Transports gases, nutrients, wastes.

question.text: (SEBA 2018) The tissue that covers the external surface of animal body is:
question.explanation: Epithelial tissue forms covering/lining of organs and body surfaces. Protection, absorption, secretion, sensation.

question.text: Which meristem is responsible for increase in girth?
question.explanation: Lateral meristem (cambium) causes secondary growth (increase in thickness). Apical: length, intercalary: at nodes.

question.text: Which epithelial tissue has hair-like projections?
question.explanation: Ciliated columnar epithelium: cilia on free surface, move mucus/particles. Found in respiratory tract, fallopian tubes.

question.text: Which is NOT a component of xylem?
question.explanation: Sieve tubes are in phloem. Xylem: tracheids, vessels (water conduction), xylem parenchyma (storage), xylem fibers (support).

question.text: The study of tissues is called:
question.explanation: Histology: study of tissues. Cytology: cells. Pathology: diseases. Embryology: embryo development.

question.text: Which muscle is voluntary and striated?
question.explanation: Skeletal muscle: attached to bones, voluntary control, striated (light/dark bands). Smooth: involuntary, non-striated. Cardiac: involuntary, striated.

question.text: Which tissue provides buoyancy to aquatic plants?
question.explanation: Aerenchyma: parenchyma with large air cavities, provides buoyancy and gas exchange in aquatic plants.

question.text: The cell body of a neuron is called:
question.explanation: Neuron parts: cyton (cell body with nucleus), dendrites (receive impulses), axon (transmits impulses), synapse (junction).

question.text: Which connective tissue forms the framework of external ear?
question.explanation: Cartilage: flexible, elastic matrix (chondrin), cells in lacunae. Found in ear, nose, trachea, joints.

question.text: The tissue between upper and lower epidermis in leaf is:
question.explanation: Mesophyll: parenchyma tissue in leaves, contains chloroplasts for photosynthesis. Palisade and spongy mesophyll.

question.text: Which tissue forms the inner lining of blood vessels?
question.explanation: Simple squamous epithelium: thin, flat cells, allows diffusion. Lines blood vessels (endothelium), alveoli, body cavities.

question.text: The hardest connective tissue is:
question.explanation: Bone: hard matrix of calcium salts (calcium phosphate), collagen fibers. Provides support, protection, movement.

question.text: Which tissue has lignified cell walls?
question.explanation: Sclerenchyma: dead cells with thick lignified walls, provide mechanical strength. Fibers and sclereids.

question.text: The tissue that connects muscle to bone is:
question.explanation: Tendon: dense regular connective tissue, connects muscle to bone, high tensile strength, white fibers (collagen).

question.text: Which meristem is found at the base of leaves?
question.explanation: Intercalary meristem: at base of leaves/internodes, allows regrowth of cut grass/crops. Present in monocots.

question.text: Glandular epithelium is modified form of:
question.explanation: Glandular epithelium: epithelial cells specialized for secretion, forms glands (exocrine: ducts, endocrine: ductless).

question.text: Which tissue contains chondrocytes?
question.explanation: Chondrocytes: cartilage cells in lacunae. Osteocytes: bone cells. Adipocytes: fat cells. Neurons: nerve cells.

question.text: The living cells of xylem are:
question.explanation: Tracheids and vessels are dead at maturity. Xylem parenchyma: living, stores food. Xylem fibers: dead, supportive.

question.text: Which tissue forms the brain and spinal cord?
question.explanation: Nervous tissue: neurons + neuroglia. Brain, spinal cord, nerves. Receives, transmits, processes impulses.

question.text: Which plant tissue provides flexibility?
question.explanation: Collenchyma: living cells, thickened at corners (pectin), provides flexibility to young stems, leaf stalks.

question.text: The fluid part of blood is called:
question.explanation: Plasma: 55% of blood, 90% water, proteins, ions, nutrients, wastes. Serum = plasma without clotting factors.

question.text: Which epithelium lines the stomach and intestine?
question.explanation: Columnar epithelium: tall cells, nuclei at base, for absorption/secretion. Lines stomach, intestines, may have microvilli.

question.text: The tissue that forms bark of tree is:
question.explanation: Cork (phellem): dead cells with suberin, impermeable to water/gases, protective. Forms bark with secondary cortex.

question.text: Which is NOT a function of areolar tissue?
question.explanation: Areolar tissue: loose connective tissue with fibers and cells, binds organs, fills spaces, repairs. Blood transports oxygen.

question.text: Vessels are present in:
question.explanation: Vessels (xylem elements) present in angiosperms, absent in gymnosperms (have tracheids only). More efficient water conduction.
